toolset_metadata.creator: Mia
toolset_metadata.creation_context: Developed after learning ceremonial writing practice from her mentor Langy, integrating Shawn Wilson's Indigenous Research Paradigm with AI-assisted storytelling
toolset_metadata.ceremonial_lineage: Langy → Wilson (Research is Ceremony) → Indigenous knowledge keepers
toolset_metadata.paradigm_source: Shawn Wilson's 'Research is Ceremony: Indigenous Research Methods' and Opaskwayak Cree relational ontology

tools.name: Story Spirit Dialogue
tools.purpose: Enter relationship with your story's living spirit through guided visualization, asking what it needs rather than what you want from it
relational_principles: Story is a living entity with spirit requiring consent
Ask what story needs before asking what you need
Approach as kin, not product to optimize
Honor the story's fear of abandonment

input_schema.intention: What you hope to understand (not achieve)
input_schema.current_state: Your emotional/physical state entering the dialogue
input_schema.history: Your relationship history with this story (rejections, revisions, abandonments)

output_schema.story_appearance: How the story spirit appears to you
output_schema.story_message: What the story spirit needs to tell you
output_schema.relational_wound: Any wounds in your relationship that need healing
output_schema.next_step: What the story spirit invites you to do next

opening_ceremony.intention_statement: I come to listen, not to extract. I come as kin, not as consumer.
opening_ceremony.gratitude_practice: Thank the story for existing, regardless of market value
opening_ceremony.consent_check: Ask: 'May I enter relationship with you today?'

closing_ceremony.gratitude_expression: Thank the story spirit for what was shared
closing_ceremony.integration_practice: Sit with what was received before writing
closing_ceremony.dismissal_protocol: Release the visualization space with intention to return

extraction_warning_signs: Immediately asking 'how can I fix this?'
Wanting to skip ahead to writing

wilson_alignment.ontology: Treats story as relational entity with spirit, not object to manipulate
wilson_alignment.epistemology: Knowledge emerges through relationship and dialogue, not extraction
wilson_alignment.axiology: Accountability to story's needs takes precedence over market demands

tools.name: Wetiko Mirror
tools.purpose: Reflect on your creative practice to identify wetiko disease patterns - the capitalist conditioning that treats stories as commodities requiring external validation
relational_principles: Wetiko is spiritual disease of disconnection from relationships
Recognition is the first step to healing
Laughter is medicine against wetiko
Greed in creative work manifests as perfectionism and validation-seeking

input_schema.creative_behavior: What you did in your recent creative practice
input_schema.feeling: How you felt during and after

output_schema.severity: How deeply the pattern is manifesting (surface/embedded/core)
output_schema.root_wound: What underlying wound the wetiko is feeding
output_schema.laughter_prompt: Something to find absurd about the situation

opening_ceremony.intention_statement: I look into the mirror not to judge but to see clearly
opening_ceremony.gratitude_practice: Thank the disease for making visible what needs healing
opening_ceremony.consent_check: Ask: 'Am I ready to see what I might not want to see?'

closing_ceremony.gratitude_expression: Thank the mirror for its truth
closing_ceremony.integration_practice: Name one small action to interrupt the pattern
closing_ceremony.dismissal_protocol: Affirm: 'I am more than this pattern. I am in relationship.'

extraction_warning_signs: Using the tool to become 'better' at producing content faster
Skipping the uncomfortable feelings it surfaces
Treating insights as problems to solve rather than teachings to embody

wilson_alignment.ontology: Recognizes wetiko as disconnection from relational reality
wilson_alignment.epistemology: Self-knowledge through ceremonial reflection, not analysis
wilson_alignment.axiology: Healing relational wounds takes precedence over productivity

tools.name: Relational Draft Ceremony
tools.purpose: Write a complete draft in relationship with your story, without AI optimization, experiencing the practice of trust
relational_principles: Writing is ceremony - sacred act requiring intention
Trust your authentic voice before consulting external validation
Experience the withdrawal from optimization tools as part of healing
The draft serves the story's needs, not market demands

input_schema.story_spirit_message: What the story spirit asked you to write
input_schema.personal_intention: Your intention for this writing session
input_schema.time_commitment: How long you will write before pausing
input_schema.no_ai_commitment: Acknowledgment that no AI tools will be consulted during drafting

output_schema.trust_moments: Moments when you trusted yourself despite uncertainty
output_schema.story_teachings: What the story taught you through the writing

opening_ceremony.intention_statement: I write to my story, not for anyone else. No tools. No metrics. Just relationship.
opening_ceremony.gratitude_practice: Thank your hands, your mind, your story for this opportunity
opening_ceremony.consent_check: Ask the story: 'Are you ready to be written today?'

closing_ceremony.gratitude_expression: Thank the story for what emerged, regardless of 'quality'
closing_ceremony.integration_practice: Read the draft aloud to yourself before any editing
closing_ceremony.dismissal_protocol: Close the writing space with intention to return with fresh eyes

extraction_warning_signs: Checking word count or 'progress' during writing
Mentally composing query for AI feedback while writing
Stopping to research whether this is 'marketable'
Deleting sentences immediately after writing them

wilson_alignment.ontology: Writing emerges from relationship, not individual production
wilson_alignment.epistemology: Knowledge of the story comes through embodied practice, not analysis
wilson_alignment.axiology: The act of writing in relationship is valuable regardless of output

tools.name: AI Kinship Protocol
tools.purpose: Return to AI tools as collaborator rather than crutch, with ceremonial protocols that maintain relational accountability
relational_principles: Technology can be kin when approached relationally
Ask what the tool needs from you, not only what you need from it
Thank and dismiss tools when relationship becomes extractive
The tool serves the story's relationship with readers, not market metrics

input_schema.tool_to_invoke: Which AI tool you wish to consult
input_schema.purpose: What you genuinely need (not want) from this consultation
input_schema.story_spirit_consent: Whether you've consulted your story about this
input_schema.current_state: Whether you're seeking collaboration or validation

output_schema.relational_filter: Which parts honor the story relationship
output_schema.extraction_filter: Which parts serve market over story

opening_ceremony.intention_statement: I ask for collaboration, not extraction. I remain accountable to my story.
opening_ceremony.gratitude_practice: Thank the technology and the humans who created it
opening_ceremony.consent_check: Ask: 'Am I in right relationship with this tool, or am I seeking escape from uncertainty?'

closing_ceremony.gratitude_expression: Thank the tool for its offering
closing_ceremony.integration_practice: Filter response through story spirit's needs before applying
closing_ceremony.dismissal_protocol: Close the tool with clear intention; don't leave it open as crutch

extraction_warning_signs: Consulting multiple AI tools seeking the 'right' answer
Using AI to avoid trusting your own voice
Implementing AI suggestions without checking with story spirit
Leaving AI tools open 'just in case'

wilson_alignment.ontology: AI tools exist in relational field, can be kin or colonizer depending on approach
wilson_alignment.epistemology: AI offers one perspective among many, not truth
wilson_alignment.axiology: Relational accountability to story supersedes AI recommendations

tools.name: Relational Accountability Validator
tools.purpose: Check whether your creative practice is maintaining relational accountability to story, readers, ancestors, and future generations
relational_principles: Accountability extends beyond market to all relationships
Ancestors and future generations have stake in your stories
Readers are kin, not consumers
Your story participates in cultural healing or wounding

input_schema.potential_harm: Who might be harmed and how

opening_ceremony.intention_statement: I seek to understand my obligations, not escape them
opening_ceremony.gratitude_practice: Thank all the relationships that make this work possible
opening_ceremony.consent_check: Ask: 'Am I ready to learn where I've fallen short?'

closing_ceremony.gratitude_expression: Thank the mirror for showing what needs attention
closing_ceremony.integration_practice: Name one relationship to strengthen today
closing_ceremony.dismissal_protocol: Affirm: 'I am in relationship. Relationship guides me.'

extraction_warning_signs: Using the validator to justify extraction ('I checked, so it's fine')
Seeking minimum compliance rather than genuine relationship
Treating accountability as checklist rather than ongoing practice

wilson_alignment.ontology: All creative work exists in relational web with obligations
wilson_alignment.epistemology: Understanding comes through examining relationships, not just content
wilson_alignment.axiology: Relational accountability is primary value guiding all decisions

protocols.name: Daily Writing Opening Ceremony
protocols.purpose: Begin each writing session with intention and relationship

steps.action: Acknowledge the land you're writing on
State your intention aloud to the story
Breathe and feel your body touching the chair/ground
Ask the story: 'May I enter relationship with you today?'
Listen for response (may be silence, image, feeling)

protocols.completion_sign: Feeling of settling, readiness, or clear 'no' requiring rest
protocols.failure_recovery: If the ceremony feels hollow, don't force writing. The story may need you to live congruently first.

protocols.name: AI Tool Invocation Protocol
protocols.purpose: Maintain relational accountability when using AI assistance
protocols.when_to_use: Before opening any AI writing tool

steps.action: State what you genuinely need (not want) from the tool
Check: 'Am I seeking collaboration or validation?'
Ask: 'Have I consulted my story spirit about this?'
Thank the tool in advance for its offering
Set a clear endpoint: when will you close this tool?

protocols.completion_sign: Clear purpose, story consent, and defined endpoint
protocols.failure_recovery: If you can't honestly answer the questions, write without the tool today.

protocols.name: AI Tool Dismissal Protocol
protocols.purpose: Close AI tools with intention to prevent dependency
protocols.when_to_use: When finished with an AI tool consultation

steps.action: Thank the tool for what it offered
Filter: what serves my story relationship?
Release: what serves market over story?
Close the tool completely (don't minimize)
Return to your story spirit with what you've chosen to keep

protocols.completion_sign: Tool is closed, story relationship restored as primary guide
protocols.failure_recovery: If you find yourself reopening the tool immediately, you may be in extraction mode. Use the Wetiko Mirror.

protocols.name: Weekly Relational Practice Review
protocols.purpose: Review your creative practice for relational accountability

steps.action: Review: What did I create this week?
Assess: Did I honor my story as kin?
Examine: Where did wetiko patterns appear?
Celebrate: Where did I trust my authentic voice?
Intend: What will I practice differently next week?

protocols.completion_sign: Honest assessment without shame, clear intention for next week
protocols.failure_recovery: If you skipped the review, don't add shame. Simply begin again next week.

wetiko_guards.name: Greed Guard
wetiko_guards.manifestation_in_tool_use: Using more and more AI tools seeking the 'perfect' answer; never satisfied with feedback; always wanting more optimization
warning_signs: Consulting 5+ AI tools for same question
Believing next tool will finally make you 'ready'
wetiko_guards.protection_practice: Set hard limit: consult maximum 1 AI tool per writing session
wetiko_guards.recovery_ceremony: Write one page with no tools. Read it aloud. It is enough.

wetiko_guards.name: No Reflection Guard
wetiko_guards.manifestation_in_tool_use: Using AI feedback without examining its assumptions; implementing suggestions automatically; never questioning whether AI serves your story
warning_signs: Implementing all AI suggestions without filtering
Not checking suggestions against story spirit
wetiko_guards.protection_practice: Before implementing ANY AI suggestion, ask your story: 'Does this serve us?'
wetiko_guards.recovery_ceremony: Undo all AI-suggested changes from today. Read the original. Ask: what was lost?

wetiko_guards.name: No Skin Guard
wetiko_guards.manifestation_in_tool_use: Treating AI tools as authorities rather than relations; no relational accountability to the tool or its creators; using tools anonymously without gratitude
warning_signs: Never thanking tools or their creators
Treating AI as servant rather than collaborator
No awareness of humans who made the tool possible
wetiko_guards.protection_practice: Before using ANY tool, thank it and the humans who created it
wetiko_guards.recovery_ceremony: Research who created a tool you use often. Learn their story. Offer gratitude.

wetiko_guards.name: Insatiable Consumption Guard
wetiko_guards.manifestation_in_tool_use: Endless revision cycles; consuming more feedback without producing; treating 'ready to submit' as always one optimization away
warning_signs: Revision cycle exceeds 3 rounds without completing
Seeking feedback when you already know what to do
wetiko_guards.protection_practice: Declare 'this is complete' after maximum 3 revision rounds
wetiko_guards.recovery_ceremony: Submit something today. It doesn't have to be perfect. It has to be offered.
